perturbation.original_text:
4.5. PAYMENT TERMS. Impresse shall pay the fees set forth in Sections
4.2  [SLOTTING FEES], 4.3  [BANNER/NEWSLETTER PURCHASE COMMITMENT] and 4.4  [HOSTING FEE] as an aggregate, totaling $[*] payable in four equal
quarterly installments of $[*] beginning on May 31, 2000 and thereafter on
August 31, 2000 November 30, 2000 and February 28, 2001, respectively.
perturbation.changed_text:
4.5. PAYMENT TERMS. Impresse shall pay the fees set forth in Sections
4.2  [SLOTTING FEES], 4.3  [BANNER/NEWSLETTER PURCHASE COMMITMENT] and 4.4  [HOSTING FEE] as an aggregate, totaling $[*] payable in four equal
quarterly installments of $[*] beginning on May 31, 2000 and thereafter on
August 31, 2000 November 30, 2000 and February 28, 2001, respectively. However, if Impresse experiences a revenue shortfall of 15% or more in any quarter, the payment for that quarter may be deferred by up to 90 days with no penalty.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction regarding payment deadlines. The original clause specifies fixed payment dates. The added sentence allows for a 90-day deferral under certain conditions, creating uncertainty about the actual due dates and potentially conflicting with other clauses that might reference the original payment schedule, creating ambiguity about when payments are definitively due.

perturbation.original_text:
4.9. INTEREST. All payments not paid by the date such payments are due
shall bear interest from the due date to the date payments are actually paid at
the lower of (i) 1% per month or (ii) the maximum rate permitted by law.
perturbation.changed_text:
4.9. INTEREST. All payments not paid by the date such payments are due
shall bear interest from the due date to the date payments are actually paid at
the lower of (i) 1% per month or (ii) the maximum rate permitted by law. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no interest shall accrue on payments deferred under the provisions outlined in Section 4.5.
perturbation.explanation: This change creates a direct contradiction regarding interest on late payments. The original clause mandates interest on all late payments. The added exception removes interest for deferred payments under section 4.5. This creates uncertainty and disputes can arise as to whether or not interest should be accrued if the payments are deferred according to Section 4.5.

perturbation.original_text:
5.2. Either party may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written
notice to the other party in the event of any material breach of a term of this
Agreement by such other party that remains uncured 30 days after written notice
of such breach was received by such other party or, if the breach is not
reasonably capable of cure within 30 days, such longer period, not to exceed 60
days, so long as the cure is commenced within the 30-day period and thereafter
is diligently prosecuted to completion as soon as possible and in any event
within 60 days.
perturbation.changed_text:
5.2. Either party may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written
notice to the other party in the event of any material breach of a term of this
Agreement by such other party that remains uncured 30 days after written notice
of such breach was received by such other party or, if the breach is not
reasonably capable of cure within 30 days, such longer period, not to exceed 60
days, so long as the cure is commenced within the 30-day period and thereafter
is diligently prosecuted to completion as soon as possible and in any event
within 60 days. However, failure by Impresse to make timely payments, even if deferred under Section 4.5, shall constitute immediate grounds for termination by VerticalNet, without any cure period.
perturbation.explanation: This perturbation creates a contradiction regarding the termination conditions related to payment. Section 5.2 outlines a cure period for breaches. The added text allows VerticalNet to terminate immediately for payment failures by Impresse even if the payment is deferred per Section 4.5, thereby bypassing the standard cure period and creating ambiguity about the termination process and undermining the clause about deferred payments in Section 4.5.
